document.docAuthor: Cadena-Castañeda, Oscar J. & Díaz, Carlos Julio Arango & López, Víctor Hugo Grande & Cárdenas, Andrea Del Pilar Floréz
document.docTitle: Studies on Neotropical crickets: New species and notes on the classification of Field Crickets genera Anurogryllus and Gryllus (Orthoptera: Gryllidae: Gryllinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Studies on Neotropical crickets: New species and notes on the classification of Field Crickets genera Anurogryllus and Gryllus (Orthoptera: Gryllidae: Gryllinae)

emphasis.docTitle:
Studies on Neotropical crickets: New species and notes on the classification of Field Crickets genera
Anurogryllus
and
Gryllus
( Orthoptera : Gryllidae : Gryllinae )

subSection.paragraph:
OSCAR J. CADENA-CASTAÑEDA 1* , CARLOS JULIO ARANGO DÍAZ 1,2,3 , VÍCTOR HUGO GRANDE LÓPEZ 2,4 &
ANDREA DEL PILAR FLORÉZ CÁRDENAS
2,5

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation:
Universidad Distrital Francisco José de Caldas . Grupo de Investigación en Artrópodos “Kumangui”, Bogotá , Colombia .
2 Universidad INCCA de Colombia . Grupo en Ecología Evolutiva y Biogeografía Tropical ECOBIT.

subSection.paragraph:
3
� carlosjulio91449@hotmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8108-1054

4

vhgrandel@unincca.edu.co ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0003-0475-6975

* Corresponding author.
� ojccorthoptera@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0001-5646-0602

In this contribution to the American Field and Short-tail crickets, two new species from the continental and insular area of Colombia are described.
Anurogryllus ( Urogryllus ) edithsantosum
n. sp.
from the Meta department , is more related to some Caribbean species, and its genital structure fits the morphological current definition of the subgenus
Urogryllus
, although it has pseudepiphallic median lophi covered with hairs, as it happens in the species of the subgenus Pilosogryllus . The same way,
Gryllus ( Gryllus ) providiensis
n. sp.
from Providencia Island, San Andres Archipelago is described, this new species has thick hairs on the pronotum as
Gryllus ( Gryllus ) assimilis
(widely distributed in America), as well as the color pattern of the cephalic capsule; but the new species is smaller in size, and has a particular organization in the harp veins of the tegmina, which only resembles
Gryllus ( Gryllus ) marchena
from the Galapagos Archipelago ( Ecuador ), from which it differs markedly in its morphology. Finally, the status of the
Gryllus species
, distributed in Latin America and the Caribbean, is reviewed, and it is recorded which species have acoustic records, and from here we start with the review of this peculiar genus in Latin America.
Key words: Cricket diversity, Latin America, Caribbean, genital morphology

En esta contribución a los grillos de campo americanos se describe dos nuevas especies del área continental e insular de Colombia .
Anurogryllus ( Urogryllus ) edithsantosum
n. sp.
proveniente del departamento del Meta , y que está más relacionada con algunas especies caribeñas, y en su estructura genital encaja a la definición morfológica del subgénero
Urogryllus
, aunque presenta el lóbulo medio del pseudepifalo cubierto de pelos, tal como sucede en las especies del subgénero Pilosogryllus . De igual modo, se describe a
Gryllus ( Gryllus ) providiensis
n. sp.
de la Isla de Providencia, Archipiélago de San Andrés, esta nueva especie presenta pelos gruesos en el pronoto como en
Gryllus ( Gryllus ) assimilis
(ampliamente distribuida en América), al igual que el patrón de coloración de la capsula cefálica; pero la nueva especie es de menor tamaño, y tiene una organización particular en las venas del harpa de la tegmina, que solo se asemeja a
Gryllus ( Gryllus ) marchena
del Archipiélago de Galápagos ( Ecuador ), de la cual difiere notoriamente en su morfología. Finalmente, se revisa el estatus de las especies del género
Gryllus
, distribuidas en Latinoamérica y el Caribe, y se registra que especies tienen registros acústicos y de aquí partir en la revisión de este peculiar género en Latinoamérica.
Palabras clave: Diversidad de grillos, Latinoamérica, Caribe, morfología genital

Generally, field crickets occur on the ground, building galleries, from where the males sing to attract conspecific females, finding tiny species (from 8 mm ) such as those grouped in
Perugryllus Jaiswara, 2017
or
Atsigryllus Cadena-Castañeda & Tíjaro 2020
, even larger genera such as
Titanogryllus
Jaiswara et al ., 2018
,
Megalogryllus Chopard, 1930
or
Gigagryllus Cadena-Castañeda & García García, 2020
( 29-38 mm .) (
Jaiswara et al ., 2018
; Cadena-Castañeda & Tíjaro 2020 ; Cadena-Castañeda & García García, 2020 ). Some species have considerably expanded their distribution, owing to human settlements, being introduced from other countries or continents ( Desutter, 1990 ; Cadena-Castañeda, 2011, Gorochov, 2019 ). Several species have become models for studies in different fields of science, either because of cryptic speciation (for example,
Gryllus Linnaeus, 1758 species
) ( Weissman & Gray, 2019 ,
Gray et al ., 2020
) or they can be used for physiological analysis or as a source of protein for food (
Weissman et al ., 2012
).

The present contribution records and describes new species of the genera
Anurogryllus Saussure, 1877
and
Gryllus
from Colombia . This paper is the continuation to the study of the Colombian Gryllidea and another adjacent regions, with previous contributions to Gryllidae ( Cadena-Castañeda, 2011a , Cadena-Castañeda & Noriega, 2015 ; Cadena-Castañeda & Tíjaro, 2020 ; Cadena-Castañeda & García García, 2020 ; Desutter et al ., 2014),
Phalangopsidae ( Cadena-Castañeda & García García, 2012 )
and Gryllotalpidae ( Cadena-Castañeda 2011b , 2015a , b). More contributions to Grylloidea and Gryllotalpoidea are coming forward for future publications.

Specimen preparation. The studied specimens were deposited at the Museo de Historia Natural de la Universidad Distrital Francisco José de Caldas , Colección de Entomología y Aracnología ( CAUD ). Lateral and dorsal view photographs were taken with a Nikon D3400 digital camera, and the remaining morphological characters with a Carl Zeiss Stemi 2000–C stereomicroscope.

The dissection of genitalia was made based on Cadena-Castañeda’s work (2015a). Male genitalia follow Desutter (1987) , modified in Desutter-Grandcolas (2003) : arc , ectophallic arc ec.f ., ectophallic fold, en.c ., endophallic cavity, l.l ., pseudepiphallic lateral lophi, m.l ., pseudepiphallic median lophi, ps.a ., pseudepiphallic apodeme, ps.p ., pseudepiphallic paramere, r. , rami, d. cav. , dorsal cavity. The wing venation nomenclature we follow Desutter-Grancolas et al . (2017).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Comments. This genus is distributed from the United States to Argentina , including the Greater and Lesser Antilles. Contains 37 species in four recently established subgenera (
Cigliano et al ., 2021
). They are known by the common name of “Short-tailed cricket” because at least in the subgenus
Anurogryllus
, the ovipositor of females is very short and slightly exceeds the length of the subgenital plate ( Walker, 1973 ), females of the other subgenera have a welldeveloped ovipositor, sometimes exceeding the length of the hind femur ( Randell, 1964 ; Gorochov, 2019 ), discarding the ovipositor length as a generic character, as was the case in the past, and rather, it is the structure of the male genitalia which defines the genus ( Randell, 1964 ; García-Novo, 2002).
Anurogryllus
is very diverse since the range of its distribution has several gaps where in the future many species may be found since the distribution of its species is restricted (except
Anurogryllus ( Anurogryllus ) muticus (De Geer, 1773))
and several examples are sympatric.
http://lsid.speciesfile.org/urn:lsid: Orthoptera .speciesfile.org:TaxonName:514177

Etymology. Dedicated to the memory of the social leader Edith del Consuelo Santos Jiménez, murdered in 2014, in the Chichimene village, Acacias, Meta , for her defense of the environment and the people of the oil sector.

Type material.
Holotype .
Male. Colombia , Meta , Acacias , Vrd. La Esmeralda , Finca La Bonita. 3.972 260, -73.726315.
514 m
.
21 April 2004
. J. Molano ( CAUD )
.
Paratype
. Male, same data as holotype.

Description. Male. Large size for the genus ( Fig. 1A, B ). Coloration. Head, thorax and abdomen dark brown; legs and ventral surface of body yellowish brown. Head with bands alternating shades of brown; eyes black with depigmented ommatidia in the supra-internal region; ocelli and mouthparts ocher, labial palps and jaws yellow; translucent tegminae with yellow venation. Head. Rounded and as wide as the pronotal disc; frons between antennal cavities 1.5 times as wide as scape; ocelli moderately large and located almost on one transverse line, median ocellus transverse and lateral ones round. Maxillary palp with five palpomeres, first and second shorter, third larger than fourth, fifth-largest, enlarged, apex truncated and grooved ( Fig. 2A ). Thorax. Pronotum pubescent, with thicker bristles at the edges; anterior edge of the pronotal disc with concave central portion, straight posterior edge; midline crossing from the anterior to the posterior edge of the pronotal disc, and on each side, a mark in leaf form, no varying in color with the rest of the pronotum. Legs. Pubescents; fore and mid legs similar; fore tibia with one external and two internal apical spurs, outer tympanum large and ovoid, inner tympanum very small and rounded; hind tibia with seven pairs of dorsal spines; hind basitarsus with two rows of dorsal denticles, seven inner and eight outer, two apical spurs, the internal longer than the external. Wings. Tegmina ovoid and covering only the first abdominal segment and the base of the second one ( Fig. 2B ); stridulatory file with 101 teeth ( Fig. 2C ), basal area reduced, A3 vein very reduced almost covering the anterior edge of the pronotum when the tegmina is at rest, harp with two diagonal veins, the chordal area with veins Cu2 and 1A parallel and arcuate, veins 2A and 3A parallel to the tegmen edge, two small veins connecting the Cu2 vein to the mirror; apical area reduced and reticulate; mirror divided by a vein very close to the inner-lower edge ( Fig. 2B ). Hind wings reduced. Abdomen. Epiproctus with moderately elongated and rounded posterior edge; subgenital plate rectangular, longer than wide and with a rounded apex. Genitalia. Pseudepiphallic median lophi elongated and lanceolated in ventral and dorsal view ( Fig. 3A, C ), moderately flared, with a deep U-shaped notch at the apex, lateral edges with abundant hairs; pseudepiphallic parameres slender and shorter than the median lophi, apex truncated and ondulated ( Fig. 3A, B ); lateral lophi shorth and hook-shaped; ectophallic fold ribbon-shaped, narrow and sticking out between the pseudepiphallic median lophi and parameres, apex lanceolated ( Fig. 3A ); arc narrow, as a plate up-curved dorsally ( Fig. 3C, D ); endophallic cavity membranous and ovoid ( Fig. 3C, D ); quadrangular rami connected in the posterior portion ( Fig. 3A–D ).
Female. Unknown.
Measurements (mm): LB: 11–12. Pr: 4–4.5. Teg.: 6–6.5. HF: 14. HT: 10.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Anurogryllus ( Urogryllus ) edithsantosum
n. sp.
male habitus A. Lateral and B. Dorsal view respectively.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Comparison. This new species is more similar to Caribbean species such as A. ( U .) amolgos Otte & Perez-Gelabert, 2009 , A. ( U .) gnomus Otte & Perez-Gelabert, 2009 and A. ( U .) nigua Otte & Perez-Gelabert, 2009 , than the continental species of the subgenus
Urogryllus
. It is distinguished from A. ( U .) amolgos because the tegmina reach the base of the second abdominal tergite and the apex of the median lophi is lanceolate and without undulations on the lateral edges of the new species, in contrast, A. ( U .) amolgos the tegmina cover slightly more than half of the abdomen and the apex of the median lophi is narrow and wavy. A.
( U .) edithsantosum
n. sp.
differs in the incision of the median lophi, which is deeper and wider to A. ( U .) gnomus . The new species has the ectophallic fold of medium size, but in A . ( U .) nigua is elongated, in lateral view the median lophi and lateral lophi of pseudepiphallus looks altogether like a snout, and between these the ectophallic fold emerges like a tongue. A.
( U .) edithsantosum
n. sp.
differs from the three mentioned species, in its larger size, brown color of the head, and the pseudepiphallic median lophi is covered with hairs (as the species of the subgenus Pilosogryllus ), in contrast, the other species are of medium to small size, the head is black, and the pseudepiphallic median lophi is hairless.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Anurogryllus ( Urogryllus ) edithsantosum
n. sp. A.
Frons and legs. B. Tegmina. C. Stridulation file.

FIGURE 3.
Anurogryllus ( Urogryllus ) edithsantosum
n. sp.
male genitalia A. Ventral. B. Axial. C. Dorsal and D. Lateral view respectively.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Comments. This is the type genus of the family, with a wide distribution on the planet, although without records in Australia , where it has been replaced by
Teleogryllus Chopard, 1961
( Chopard, 1961 ;
Cigliano et al . 2021
). Contains 101 species in two subgenera, the subgenus
Gryllus
with most species and Homaloblemus Saussure, 1877 with two African species with distinctly modified head ( Gorochov, 2001 ). They are known by the common name of Field Crickets, although it is a term used indiscriminately for members of the subfamily Gryllinae . A new species from the Caribbean and a preliminary analysis of the Latin American species are described below.
http://lsid.speciesfile.org/urn:lsid: Orthoptera .speciesfile.org:TaxonName:514178
Etymology. It refers to the Providencia Island, Archipelago of San Andres , from where this species was collected.

Type material.
Holotype .
Male. Colombia , Providencia Island , road to “Pico” 13.346 994, -81.374616.
300 m
.
J. Arias ( CAUD )
.
Paratypes .
Female adult, two females and one male subadults with same data as holotype
.

Description. Male. Mid-size for the genus ( Fig. 4A, B ). Coloration. Head with the dorsal surface from the vertex to the fastigium, between the middle of the antennal sockets and partially the clypeus dark brown, the rest of the cephalic capsule ocher including the jaws; ocelli and palps light yellow; lateral ocelli joined by an ocher inverted “Y” (epicraneal suture); eyes black with depigmented ommatidia in the supra-internal region ( Fig. 5A ). Pronotal disc and partially the lateral lobes of the pronotum dark brown, with the lower half whitish-yellow ( Fig. 4A ). Meso and metathorax light yellow, legs light ocher, although the tibiae have brown bristles. Tegmina ochre with the base with a light-yellow spot ( Fig. 4B ), veins with brown and ocher portions. Dark brown abdomen. Head. Rounded and as wide as the pronotal disc; frons between antennal cavities 1.5 times as wide as scape; ocelli moderately large and located almost on one transverse line, median ocellus transverse and lateral ones round. Maxillary palp with five palpomeres, first and second shorter, third almost as long as the fourth, fifth-largest, enlarged, apex rounded, devoid of the cuticle covering the others of the segments ( Fig. 5A ). Thorax. Pronotum pubescent, with thicker bristles on the edges; anterior edge of pronotal disc concave, posterior edge convex; midline traversing from the anterior edge, interrupting near the posterior edge of the pronotal disc, and on each side, a mark in leaf form, no varying in color with the rest of the pronotal disc ( Fig. 4A, B ). Legs. Pubescent; with conspicuous bristles on the dorsal edge of the femora, fore and mid legs similar; fore tibia with one outer and two inner apical spurs, outer tympanum large and ovoid, inner tympanum small and rounded; hind tibia with eight outer-dorsal and five inner-dorsal spines; hind basitarsus with two rows of dorsal denticles, four inner and six outer, two apical spurs, the internal longer than the external. Wings. Tegmina covering up to the seventh abdominal segment ( Fig. 4B , 5B ); stridulatory file with 130 teeth; harp with three diagonal veins ( Fig. 5C ), first or proximal harp vein originating near the base of the second or mid harp vein, in turn, the first or proximal harp vein branching out in the first basal third of its length, this branching is hardly visible, tenuous and does not lead on the Cu1 vein (or Branch of CuPB sensu Desutter-Grandcolas et al ., (2017)), as if the other veins of the harp do. Chordal area with all three veins present, veins Cu2 and 1A parallel and arcuate; mirror divided as normally happens in species of this genus; apical area developed and reticulated ( Fig. 5C ). Hind wings widely exceeding the abdomen. Abdomen. Epiproct semi-oval, the base of straight lateral edges and protruding dorsally like keels. Subgenital plate longer than wide and with the apex divided into a medial incision. Genitalia. Three typical projections of the pseudepiphallic lophi region, similar to other species of the genus ( Fig. 6A–C ).
Measurements (mm) male/female: LB: 17/20. Pr: 3.5/4. Teg.: 12/14. HF: 8/9. HT: 7.5/8.

Comparison. This new species is similar to
G . ( G .) assimilis
in its habitus, conspicuous bristles in the pronotum, epicranial suture and pale circumocular area, although the new species is smaller than
G . ( G. ) assimilis
, and the venation of the tegmina is different (
G . ( G. ) assimilis
have 4–5 harp veins). Although the coloration of the
Gryllus species
is variable, some patterns remain, and the new species has yellow legs and wings (especially the tegmina with a light-yellow spot at the base), in contrast,
G . ( G. ) assimilis
has darker coloring patterns, usually with legs and tegmina in shades of brown.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Gryllus ( Gryllus ) providiensis
n. sp.
male habitus A. Lateral and B. Dorsal view respectively.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Few
Gryllus species
have less than 4 harp veins, in the Caribbean species, it happens in
G . ( G. ) arijua Otte & Perez-Gelabert, 2009
and
G . ( G. ) providiensis
n. sp.
in both there are 3 veins, but in
G . ( G. ) arijua
all originate from the stridulation vein (Cu2 traditionally, CuPb vein sensu Desutter-Grandcolas et al ., (2017)), but in the new species, only the second and third veins of the harp are born from the stridulating crest, the first vein arises from the second vein and in turn branches into a thin and short vein that is not considered an additional vein of the harp, this is peculiar to
G . ( G. ) providiensis
n. sp.
, as the well-documented Caribbean and Neotropical species do not have this condition. The new species also differs from
G . ( G .) arijua
, in its coloration and length of the tegmina, which reaches the seventh abdominal segment, in contrast,
G . ( G. ) arijua
, has darker tones, resembling more to
G . ( G .) assimilis
, brown hind femur, with dark brown stripes and the tegmina covers until the last abdominal segment.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Gryllus ( Gryllus ) providiensis
n. sp. A.
Frons and legs. B. Tegmina. C. Stridulation file.

FIGURE 6.
Gryllus ( Gryllus ) providiensis
n. sp.
male genitalia A. Ventral. B. Dorsal and C. Lateral view respectively.

FIGURE 7.
Gryllus ( Gryllus ) providiensis
n. sp.
female habitus A. Lateral. B. Dorsal view. C. Frons and legs.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Comments. Recent publications have suggested using acoustic data to complement the description of new taxa for
Gryllus
, since they do not present significant variability that allows defining species with genitalia, as is traditionally done with crickets ( Weissman & Gray, 2019 ). But the description of
G . ( G .) providiensis
n. sp.
, maybe an exception, due to its particular morphology, differing conspicuously from the closest species, as mentioned in the comparison. Also, the organization of the harp veins is not shared with the other Caribbean and continental species. Only
G . ( G. ) marchena Otte & Peck, 1997
from the Galapagos Archipelago has a similar pattern, but this species differs from
G . ( G .) providiensis
n. sp.
since all the Galapagean species have short wings and a more elongated ovipositor, and a completely black cephalic head.

heading.emphasis:
About the status of
Gryllus species

subSection.paragraph:
The taxonomy in this genus is complex since morphologically they are similar, including the male genitalia ( Chopard, 1961 ), the separation of species by morphological methods is laborious, the song is necessary for a positive identification ( Weissman & Gray, 2019 ). The identity of North American species has been studied and their genetic and acoustic limits have been established ( Weissman & Gray, 2019 ;
Gray et al ., 2020
), but for Central and South America the separation and delimitation of the species has not been possible, with methods similar to those used with North American taxa. On the contrary, the Central and South American species were described a long time ago, with specimens mostly without precise localities, or based on females, and several of the species are missing type specimens, making it even more difficult to identify species. The data for the type specimens of the
Gryllus species
discussed below are given by
Hollier et al . (2013)
.

For the species,
Gryllus ( Gryllus ) chichimecus Saussure, 1897
,
G. ( G. ) miopteryx Saussure, 1877
, G.
( G .) bicolor Saussure, 1874
and
G. ( G .) assimilis
pallida Saussure, 1897, their type specimens are lost, and they have not been found in any European collection where Henri de Saussure usually studied and deposited his specimens. In addition, the localities are imprecise, the descriptions are very brief. Taking into account the uniformity of the generic morphology, it makes it impossible to identify these species with the available information.
G. ( G .) assimilis
pallida is considered a variety of
G . assimilis
in its original description, but currently, specimens with locality data are labeled with specimens identified as
G. aztecus Saussure, 1859
(current synonym of
G. assimilis
), questioning the validity of
G. ( G .) assimilis
pallida . G.
( G .) bicolor
from Guyana , with the missing type specimen, a male with a locality of Peru is referenced as this species, but it is not considered a type specimen, so the identity of this species cannot be certified. With the current status of these species, we would consider them as nomina dubia . Recent communication with Dr. David Weissman indicates he is preparing a manuscript in which he will designate neotypes for them. For this reason, we abstain from proposing these species as nomina dubia and we look forward to the future contribution by Dr. Weissman.

The status of four other species should be reviewed, even though the type specimens exist, but are in poor condition, the localities are imprecise, and the types are females (practically impossible to reliably identify) and no relevant data has been provided since their original description, do not allow a good identification: 1)
G. ( G. ) mundus Walker, 1869
described with locality Brazil and proposed by
Weissman et al . (1980)
as a synonym of
G. assimilis
, but recently revalidated (
Weissman et al . 2009
). This species was described based on a female, and due to its imprecise distribution in one of the most biodiverse regions of the planet, it makes it difficult to identify multiple species that may inhabit Brazil . 2)
G. ( G. ) signatus Walker, 1869
described with locality “ Venezuela ”, was described based on non-conspecific female and male, the brief description focused on the characters of the female ( Walker, 1869 ), with the latter the name-bearing specimen. No additional data has been provided since its description permits identification. 3)
G. ( G. ) contingens Walker, 1869
described based on two females , one from St. Vincent and the other from Jamaica , synonymized under
G. parilis Walker, 1869
by Chopard (1967) and revalidated by
Weissman et al . (2009)
. This species is not recorded for Brazil as mentioned by
Weissman et al . (2009)
, perhaps it was confusion when revalidating the species, including the distribution of
G. parilis
. 4)
G. ( G. ) scudderianus Saussure, 1874
with locality “l’Amerique Septeptrionale” =North America, which currently includes Part of Mexico, the United States and Canada , a very wide area with numerous
Gryllus species.
On the other hand, this species was described based on a female and a male in MNHN (Paris), but currently, only one female has been found that may be the probable syntype .

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Checklist of
Gryllus species
of Latinamerica

td.taxonomicName: Gryllus ( Gryllus ) cohni Weissman, Rentz, Alexander & Loher, 1980

tr.td: Baja California Sur, near La Paz
Jamaica—widely distributed: North America, Caribbean and South America

subSection.paragraph:
There are still
Gryllus species
that were originally described only with females and accompanied by immature males in their type series. Examples such as
G. ( G. ) bermudensis Caudell, 1903
or
G. ( G. ) galapageius Scudder, 1893
, which we consider as valid because in subsequent contributions its status was clarified, including males from typical localities, complementing the morphological information with acoustic data and distribution ranges ( Leroy, 1966 ; Kevan, 1980 ; Otte & Peck, 1997 ; Otte & Perez-Gelabert, 2009 ), thus making it possible to carry out a good identification of the species, and keeping the names of both taxa stable. The
Gryllus species
described based on males, from Central and South America that still prevail are those whose acoustic repertoire is mostly unknown. These species can be studied in the future with the identification of specimens from the type localities that agree with the morphological characteristics of the types and subsequently obtain their songs.

Here we begin with the taxonomy of this recognized genus of crickets for Latin America, we hope to be able to cover and contribute as Weissman et al ., (1980) and Weissman & Gray (2019) , clarify the status of the still valid species and complete the biological data for this purpose, in addition to describing new taxa. Although it is worth noting that colleagues have given important previous contributions for species from Meso and South America: Leroy (1966) , described songs and interactions for various
Gryllus species
and other species of crickets. Otte & Peck (1997) described 7 species with the most songs, all species from the Galapagos. Desutter (1990) in her doctoral thesis includes an annex with a preliminary study of the genus, grouping species and morphospecies, with morphometric characters.
David et al . (2003)
compare the songs emitted by three morphospecies from Brazil , also includes the morphometry of the stridulation files for the recognition of cryptic species. Martins & Zefa (2011) , redescribed G
( G .) argentinus Saussure, 1874
morphologically and acoustically, this as derivative paper from Martins (2009) master’s thesis, in which he also studies two morphospecies, considered as new. Finally, the 40
Gryllus species
known for Latin America and the Caribbean are listed in Table 1 , with more valid and not dubious species in the island areas of the Caribbean and Galapagos than those found in the continental region, half of the species known to date lack acoustic data, thus suggesting that many
Gryllus species
have yet to be studied at acoustic light.

We thank David Weissman ( California Academy of Sciences) for his comments on the draft version of this contribution and his comments on the current status of some dubious
Gryllus species.
OJCC would like to express his gratitude towards the Orthopterists’ Society for funding and approval of a Ted Cohn Grant, for the purchase of equipment, which has greatly improved the quality of his work.
